editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Warden and Fellows of Merton College .

msDesc.head: GALEN, CONSTANTINE THE AFRICAN &tc.; S. XIII

msItem.note: On fol. iiv is a table of contents in an anglicana hand little later than the main contents.

msItem.locus: (fols. iii-ivv, and blank spaces left at the end of works on fols. 14–15v, 37v, 90v, 113rv, 139v, 159rv)
msItem.author: PHILIP OF CORNWALL
msItem.title: Quaestiones de Impressionibus
msItem.incipit: Ad noticiam impressionum habendam quedem oportet premittere secundum doctrinam Aristotelis in primo metheororum
msItem.explicit: sciri possunt et ideo de hiis nichil ad presens.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit Summa uel tractatus de impressionibus que fuerint ex eleuacione et depressione elementorum secundum quod diffusius traditur a philosopho in libris metheororum et celi et mundi.
msItem.note: Unpr.; eTK 0055D; Sharpe, Handlist, p. 436, both citing only Vienna, Österreichische Nationalbibl. 2897 (s. xiv), fols. 66v-75v.

msItem.author: ROGER OF SALERNO
msItem.title: Chirurgia
msItem.incipit: Post mundi fabricam eiusque decorem
msItem.note: (capitula)
msItem.incipit: Capud uulnerari diuersis modis contingit
msItem.note: Ed. S. Renzi, Collectio Salernitana, 5 vols (Naples 1852–9), II, pp. 426–96, K. Sudhoff, Studien zur Geschichte der Medizin 12 (1918), 148–236.

msItem.author: GALEN
msItem.title: De Complexionibus
msItem.note: (transl. GERARD OF CREMONA)
msItem.rubric: Incipit prima particula de complexionibus G. Summe que sunt in primo libro
msItem.incipit: Insignes antiqui medicorum et philosophorum
msItem.note: Pr. in his Opera (Venice 1490), II, fols. 233v-7v.

msItem.author: GALEN
msItem.title: De Malitia Complexionis Diuersae
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber Galieni archistratos medicorum de malicia complexionis diuerse.
msItem.incipit: Malicia complexionis diuerse quandoque in toto animalis corpore consistit
msItem.explicit: post illum librum de ingenio sanitatis.
msItem.note: Pr. in his Opera, II, fols. 237–8v.

msItem.author: GALEN
msItem.title: De Simplicis Medicinis
msItem.note: (transl. CONSTANTINE THE AFRICAN)
msItem.rubric: Incipit prima particula de simplici medicina Galieni.
msItem.incipit: Quoniam mihi necesse est hic ostendere summam utilitatem
msItem.finalRubric: Finitus est tractatus quintus libri G. in medicinis singularibus.
msItem.note: Pr. in his Opera, II, fols. 238v-300v.

msItem.author: GALEN
msItem.title: De Morbo et Accidente
msItem.rubric: Incipit prima particula de morbo et accidente.
msItem.incipit: In initio huius libri diffinire morbum oportet
msItem.explicit: semper alia sequitur quod uero non.
msItem.note: Pr. in his Opera, II, fols. 355–69.

msItem.author: GALEN
msItem.title: De Crisibus
msItem.note: (transl. WILLIAM OF MOERBEKE)
msItem.incipit: Ego non intendo in hoc meo libro determinare
msItem.explicit: et non est necessarius tractatus quartus.
msItem.note: Pr. in his Opera, I, fols. 78–95v.

msItem.author: GALEN
msItem.title: De Criticis Diebus
msItem.note: (transl. GERARD OF CREMONA)
msItem.rubric: Incipit primus liber Galeni de creticis diebus.
msItem.incipit: Et egritudinum que non paulatim minuuntur
msItem.explicit: ad finem auxilio Dei et eius adiutorio completus est tractatus tercius libri Galieni de creticis diebus.
msItem.note: Pr. in his Opera, I, fols. 96–108v.

msItem.author: GALEN
msItem.title: Megategni
msItem.note: (transl. CONSTANTINE THE AFRICAN)
msItem.incipit: Quamuis karissime fili Iohannes
Quoniam intencio gloriossimi G. in hoc libro fuit ad redarguendum semita medicorum
msItem.note: Pr., with the works of Isaac Iudaeus, Lyon 1515, II, fols. 189v-209v.

Fols. 194v-5 are filled with text by the scribe of art. 1: (1) ‘Nota de dormientibus exercitatibus opera uigilie. Si queratur de quibusdam qui dormientes exercitatur opera uigilie ... fuerit apprehensa. Explicit.’ (2) Ysa. 30. Et erit lux lune sicut lux solis ...; Inter hec omnia .in. propter hominem facta in eius lapsu sunt peiorata ... serpens grauetur. Explicit.’ (3) fol. 195 (beg. impf.) te latere quem tamen latere non possum ... et modus species et ordo.’

The original fols. 196–209 (between fols. 194–5, probably quires of 10 and 4) are lost; according to the table of contents they contained John of St Paul, De Simplici Medicina, and Constantine the African, De Gradibus.

msItem.author: CONSTANTINE THE AFRICAN
msItem.title: De Stomacho
msItem.rubric: Incipit epistola Constantini ad Alphinum episcopum Salernitanum de sanitate stomachi custodienda.
msItem.incipit: Reuerentissimo
Vestre sanctitatis altitudini
msItem.note: (capitula)
msItem.incipit: Oportet nos intelligere quod prima actio nature que fit in corpore
msItem.note: Pr. with his Opera, Basel 1536, pp. 215–74.

msItem.author: CONSTANTINE THE AFRICAN
msItem.title: De Melancholia
msItem.incipit: Cum ego Constantinus Affricanus genere Montis Cassiniensis
Est igitur morbus quod patitur corpus
msItem.note: A different version (eTK 0528C, 0864J) pr. with his Opera, pp. 280–98; ed. (with the Arabic text) K. Gerbers (Hamburg, 1977).

msItem.author: CONSTANTINE THE AFRICAN
msItem.title: De Coitu
msItem.incipit: Creator uolens genus animalium firmiter ac stabiliter permanere
msItem.note: Ed. E. Montero Cartelle, Monografías de la Universidad de Santiago de Compostela 77: Santiago de Compostela, 1983, citing this MS at p. 43f..

msItem.author: CONSTANTINE THE AFRICAN
msItem.title: De Medicinis Dissolutiuis
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt capitula in genere medicinarum dissolutiuarum.
msItem.incipit: Postquam diximus uirtutem simplicis medicine
msItem.note: An excerpt from Constantinus Africanus, Pantegni (Practica, bk. 1, cc. 68–74).
msItem.bibl: eTK 1071E, this copy only. But another is in Krakow, Bibl. Jagellon. 778 (s. xv), fol. 314rv.

msItem.author: GALEN
msItem.title: De spermate
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt capitula in electione medicine et quomodo seruientur ne uirtutem amittant.
msItem.incipit: Sperma hominis descendit ex omni humore corporis
msItem.note: Pr. in his Opera, I, fols. 38v-9v.

msItem.author: CONSTANTINE THE AFRICAN
msItem.title: De oculis
msItem.incipit: Quod in libro Pantegni et uiatico de oculis sufficienter tractauimus
Oportet medicum scire uolentem curam oculorum prius eorum naturam optime cognoscere
msItem.note: Pr., with the works of Isaac Iudaeus, Lyon 1515, II, fols. 172–8, &c.

msItem.title: De urinis significantibus mortem
msItem.incipit: (Beg. impf.) talem in dentes urinam dicunt remissionem esse caloris
msItem.note: Unpr.; eTK 0700K. In Sheffield, Central Libr., Jackson Collection 1302 (English, c. 1500), fol. 37rv, it is called ‘Practica magistri Benedicti de coloribus urinarum’ (MMBL 4. 268).

msItem.author: ?JOHN OF ST PAUL
msItem.title: De Simplici Medicina
msItem.incipit: Cogitanti mihi sepe de simplicium medicinarum uirtutibus
msItem.note: (capitula)
msItem.incipit: Perfecte igitur temperate sunt medicine
msItem.note: Ed. G. H. Kroemer (Leipzig, 1920).

msItem.author: COPHO
msItem.title: De Vrinis
msItem.rubric: Incipit tractatus de urinis secundum magistrum Cophonem.
msItem.incipit: Sciendum est in urinis duo esse consideranda colorem scil. et substantiam
msItem.note: In the lower margin of fol. 236 is ‘Modus agendi in decretalibus talis est’, s. xv.

msItem.title: The opening of art. 9 again.
msItem.rubric: Incipit epistola Constantini ad Alphinum episcopum Salernitanum de sanitate stomachi custodienda.
msItem.incipit: Reuerentissimo domini A. Salernitane ecclesie archipresuli
Vestre sanctitatis altitudini
msItem.explicit: (ends impf.) stat enim infra epar et splen’.
msItem.note: An early hand writes ‘Va—cat quia in alio loco’.

msItem.author: WILLIAM OF AUXERRE
msItem.title: Summa Aurea, fragm.
msItem.incipit: Fides est substantia ...; Sicut enim uera dilectione
msItem.explicit: (ends impf. in I. viii. 4. solut. 1; edn. vol. I, p. 132) quod si nascibilitas’.
msItem.note: Glorieux, Théol. 129b; ed. J. Ribaillier (6 vols, Grottaferrata, 1980–86). The table of contents shows that this was always the last item in the book.

The book is heavily annotated throughout by the scribes of the main text, and by small cursive hands, probably French, s. xiii, and by the scribe of art. 1, including prescriptions. Some of the annotation is in a hand very like that which annotated MS 255.

supportDesc.extent:
254 leaves (iv + 250) 310 230
220 130
The edges retrimmed affecting marginalia and spattered with red.
supportDesc.collation: A4(4 canc.), 18, 28(8 canc.), 3–410, a bifolium, 512(2 canc.), 6–910, a bifolium, 10–1110, 124(4 canc.), 5–610, 76, 8–1110, 128, 1310, 144, 1510, 166, 1710, 1810(8–10 canc.), 194(lacks 1–2; + 1 after 3), 2012; occasional leaf-numbering. Several inner bifolia are missing from quire 19.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled with pencil in 2 cols of 51 lines. Running heads between ruled lines. The outer margins of 6, 11 and the lower margins of 91, 171 excised; fol. 234 is mutil., having been torn from the upper outer corner to the inner margin at the foot; fol. 236 is (and probably always was) only 130 mm. deep. Early foliation in arabic numerals runs 1–6, 6–8, 10, 12–195, 210–48, lost (prob. 249), 252–3, 253–65.

handDesc.handNote: Several similar proficient small French early gothic bookhands, except for art. 1, in an anglicana hand, s. xiv in.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red and blue flourished initials; a very few red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; plain red or blue initials and paraphs; running heads in capitals of both colours; red highlighting.

binding.p: Standard Merton s. xvii, sewn on five bands; formerly chained from the usual position. Fols. i and 250 are paper binding leaves. fol. i was formerly a pastedown.

history.provenance: French, but in England early on. At the head of fol. ii is ‘xxii s. viij d.’, in an English hand, s. xiv.
At the head of fol. iiv is an erased cautio of ‘Noreys’ dated 1341.
Below is ‘Caucio cum 3bus supplementis xxxiii s. iiij d.’, canc. Other thoroughly-erased inscriptions occur lower down.

In the lower margin of fol. 1 is an erased inscription, s. xiv: ‘Memorand’ quod iste liber ?iacet pro Norys
et M. Bryand Norys x s. Bryand x s. ’. Of the many Oxford men named Nor(r)eys, the only one whose dates fit is Richard Norreys of Exeter diocese (BRUO 1366), who studied in Oxford at intervals between 1317 and 1345. ‘Bryand’ would then be Reginald de Bryan (BRUO 290–1), BCL by 1349, bp. of Worcester 1352–61.

Also in the lower margin of fol. 1 is ‘Liber domus scolarium de Merton in Oxon’ ex dono magistri Thome Donecan quondam socii eiusdem domus in electione philosophie ibidem annis singulis a regentibus artium eligendus.’ Duncan (BRUO 605) was fellow in 1404, still in 1420, physician to the Earl of March, Edward IV’s father, d. by Apr. 1461.
At the head of fol. 1 is the James no. ‘76’, s. xvii in.

‘2’ is inked on the foredge. Inside the front board is a sheet of paper with a table of contents, s. xvii, and ‘P. 2. 2. Art:’, canc. and replaced with ‘No. CCXIX’ and ‘N. 3. 2’ in red; the College bookplate.

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Merton College Library.
